Mike DeHaan wrote:
> The beans do not implement a common interface.  The conformity that I'm
> trying to enforce is not via the interface.  I will be using reflection and
> perhaps xjavadoc to enforce some custom rules regarding annotation tags,
> internal structure, etc...
> 
> I was able to solve my problem by creating my own TestSuite class that
> implements Test.  I added a constructor and appropriate logic to allow my
> code to pass in a custom constructor to use instead of the no-arg or String
> name args that the original TestSuite used to fire up the Tests.
> 
> protected MyTestSuite(final Class theClass, Class[] constructorArgClasses,
> Object[] constructorArgs) ...
> 
> My suite now looks like this:
> 
>         suite.addTestSuite(TestRule1.class, new Class[] {Class.class}, new
> Object[] {ClassToTest.class});
> 
> 
> I understand that this is a hack, but it allows me to proceed.  If you would
> like more information regarding my changes, let me know.  I don't think this
> is worthy of submitting as a patch/change request.  If you can think of a
> better way to handle custom constructors, please let me know.

I think what you're doing is quite close to the Parameterized Test Case 
pattern, so you're no less hacking than I was. As for being worthy of a 
patch, probably not. This is one of those local customizations that just 
isn't common enough to be part of the framework. (Not that my opinion 
matters--I'm just a user, too.)

Take care.
